title: I Got A ‚ÄúJ-Shape‚Äù Haircut ‚Äî & I Think I‚Äôve Found My Forever Style
text:
I Got A ‚ÄúJ-Shape‚Äù Haircut ‚Äî & I Think I‚Äôve Found My Forever Style

Last year, I decided I‚Äôd finally had enough of the bob haircut. Not in general ‚Äî (have you seen how good it looks on Julianne Hough?) ‚Äî just on me. While hairstylists insist it‚Äôs low-maintenance and easy to grow out, my experience was the opposite. Every morning, I‚Äôd smooth out the bumps that popped up overnight, but straightening them gave me more split ends than I could shake a bottle of Dream Lengths at. And so began the long slog of growing my hair long again.

Thanks to a few clever hair-growth products (shoutout to Typebea), it didn‚Äôt take too long for my hair to reach Rapunzel-level lengths, but I hadn‚Äôt given any thought to the style I‚Äôd like once it got there. My first stop was Pinterest, of course, and as if the app knew exactly what I wanted, it served up a handful of long, swishy, and intentionally layered cuts. I knew right away I had to take the photos to my hairstylist, Steve Braithwaite, at Larry King in London.

@jisu_sunny Soft bangs and layered cut‚ú® Transforming flat straight hair into a light, airy styleü§ç #jisusalon #melbournehairdresser #melbournehairsalon #hairtransformation #hairgoals #hairstyles ‚ô¨ Winter Ahead (with PARK HYO SHIN) : Silent Carol Ver. ‚Äì V & Park Hyo Shin

Braithwaite‚Äôs approach is collaborative ‚Äî as all good haircuts should be. Before reaching for the scissors, he hit me with a bunch of important questions: Do I like a clean, blunt finish on the ends, or some separation? (I went with clean.) Do I want layers in the back as well as the front? (Yes, for extra volume, as a recent keratin treatment left my hair feeling flat.) Do I wear my hair up? (No, so the face-framing pieces could be as short and swishy as possible.)

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs aim to bring the feathered vibe through the internal shape,‚Äù Braithwaite said, adding, ‚ÄúNot too many layers, but enough if you want a little volume ‚Äî a touch of something messy and textured. It‚Äôs nice to have options.‚Äù For the face-framing layers, he wanted to make them ‚Äúa bit more connected through the front,‚Äù so they ‚Äúflow‚Äù into one another instead of looking disjointed or fluffy.

What is the J-shape haircut?

Braithwaite started by sectioning my hair and cutting the layers at an angle to create a curve, so the first layer cupped my bottom lip, and the last ended at the center of my chest. When I took a closer look in the mirror, I noticed that those perfectly cut layers formed a soft ‚ÄúJ‚Äù shape. If traditional layered cuts swish outward, the J-shape curves inward, gently cupping the face. It‚Äôs much looser than the C-shape haircut that recently took salons by storm ‚Äî and lower-maintenance as a result. Of course, the J-shape cut has been dominating salons long before any of us gave it a playful name, but the visual cue certainly makes it easier to request (especially if your stylist likes to take creative license).

How do you style the J-shape haircut?

To style my hair, Braithwaite removed as much moisture as possible by rough-drying with a blowdryer on medium heat, then used a medium barrel brush and the dryer to smooth everything out, curving the ends under (rather than outward) to create that effortless J-shape.

Styling this haircut at home is even easier with a hot brush. After rough-drying my hair to about 80% dry, I section it and use my trusty Shark SmoothStyle Heated Comb & Blow Dryer Brush to smooth each piece under, creating that loose, face-framing shape. On days when I want to refresh the style, I reach for a flatiron ‚Äî it‚Äôs just as good at curving each layer inward, especially when I‚Äôm in a rush. You might also like the Dyson Airstrait Straightener, which takes hair from wet to dry quickly and easily.¬†

Of course, heat protection is a must. I love K18 HeatBounce Conditioning Heat Protectant, which acts like a shield against high temperatures and leaves my thick hair feeling soft and manageable.¬†

@rosalierouge Haircut for the flat/straight/ fine hair girlies! #finehairstyles #finehairtips #straighthairstyle #midlengthhair #haircut #hairstyleideas #hairtips #hairroutine #hairtok #creatorsearchinsights ‚ô¨ original sound ‚Äì Kelsey Martin

How do you ask for the J-shape haircut?

Asking for the J-shape haircut is simple. Braithwaite suggests requesting ‚Äúconnected‚Äù layers throughout the lengths and back, with face-framing layers to finish that sweep toward the face. Thanks to the swishy finish, these layers look best when blow-dried straight and tend to suit medium to long hair. Layers like these are also a great way to take some of the weight out of thick hair like mine, but if TikTok is anything to go by, they work equally well on fine hair, as the feathering lends the illusion of volume and fullness.

I can safely say that the J-shape haircut is a compliment magnet. As Braithwaite finished up ‚Äî working a bit of A Social Life For Your Hair cream through my roots and ends for extra polish ‚Äî a few of the salon‚Äôs stylists came over to check out the final look and admire his handiwork.¬†

Happily, I no longer dread styling my thick hair post-shower, and even if I wear it natural, I find that the relaxed J-shape layers work with my wavy texture rather than against it, giving my hair dimension and movement. It‚Äôs taken a few haircuts over the years, but with this one, I‚Äôm convinced I‚Äôve found my forever style.

title: Your December Horoscope Is Here ‚Äî¬†& It‚Äôs Starting Off With A Whirlwind
text:
Your December Horoscope Is Here ‚Äî¬†& It‚Äôs Starting Off With A Whirlwind

We‚Äôve made it to month 12 of 12, cosmic beings, and it‚Äôs starting off with a whirlwind.¬†The Gemini Full Moon on the 4th wants us to say everything, do everything, schedule¬†five coffee dates, and buy twelve books we‚Äôll only read three pages of. Gemini‚Äôs¬†curious, chatty, and chaotic energy can be fun ‚Äî or overwhelming ‚Äî especially¬† because it‚Äôs ruled by Mercury in Scorpio, still in its retroshade until the first week of the¬† month. Translation? Be careful not to spill your tea before it‚Äôs fully steeped. You don‚Äôt¬†have to post every realization. Mind your business and your bandwidth. It‚Äôs okay to love variety and still be discerning. Sometimes your mind just wants to spin‚Ä¶ That¬†doesn‚Äôt mean you have to follow it down every rabbit hole.¬†

Then, something rare and quietly miraculous starts building: on December 10th, Neptune¬†stations direct in Pisces, joining Saturn, who just did the same a few weeks prior. This¬†is the last time in our lifetimes that both of these outer planets will be moving forward¬†together in their shared home sign. Neptune is dreams and illusions. Saturn is structure¬†and discipline. Together, they ask: what do you want to build, and is it real enough to¬†last, but dreamy enough to still make you weep a little? This is spiritual architecture.¬†Soul strategy, sacred boundaries. It‚Äôs rare to feel this mystical and grounded at once.¬†You don‚Äôt have to ‚Äúfigure it out.‚Äù But you do have to listen, especially when the¬†guidance comes through silence, or tears, or poetry.¬†

One day later, on the 11th, Mercury enters Sagittarius, and things brighten. You‚Äôre encouraged to laugh again, to tell a story out loud, to say what you believe without¬†over-explaining it. That playful Sag energy only intensifies as the sun and Mars¬†continue moving through the sign all month, but on December 15th, Mars trades the fire¬†for earth, entering Capricorn for a six-week stay. The vibe shifts: still motivated, still¬†active, but more focused and grounded. And if you‚Äôre tempted to sprint toward the¬† finish line of the year, ask yourself why.¬†¬†

2025 is a 9 year in numerology and we are in the Year of the Snake, and these both¬†represent cycles of endings, surrender, and preparation. You don‚Äôt have to prove¬†anything right now. Mars in Capricorn wants your integrity, not your overexertion.¬†Ending the year strong might just mean getting enough sleep, finishing your personal¬†projects, or walking away from what you know doesn‚Äôt align anymore.¬†

The New Moon in Sagittarius arrives on December 19th, and it‚Äôs a beautiful reminder that¬†even if this year didn‚Äôt unfold the way you expected, hope is still alive. Sagittarius¬†teaches us how to zoom out. How to trust our own resilience. How to envision six¬†months from now and still smile. The astro new year doesn‚Äôt begin until March 21st,¬† 2026, so this is not a ‚Äúwrap it all up‚Äù kind of month ‚Äî it‚Äôs a what could grow next kind¬†of moment.¬†¬†

title: Paul Mescal & Jessie Buckley Know Hamnet Is Going To Make You Cry
text:
Paul Mescal & Jessie Buckley Know Hamnet Is Going To Make You Cry

I was warned about Hamnet. Anyone who knows me knows that I am a crier and that I am easily susceptible to emotional manipulation; whether it‚Äôs a schmaltzy commercial with an intergenerational storyline or a corny Hallmark movie about the healing capacity of Christmas, I will weep. So, when it comes to a Chloe Zhao directed, critically-lauded drama about the loss of a child and art as a tool to cope with grief, people in my life knew that it would break me. And despite their disclaimers, it did.

Hamnet unfolds slowly, telling the story of William Shakespeare (Paul Mescal) and his wife Anne Hathaway, or Agnes Shakespeare (Jessie Buckley) as she‚Äôs known in this adaptation of Maggie O‚ÄôFarrell‚Äôs book Hamnet: A Novel of the Plague, as they fall in love and have three children including their son, Hamnet. The names Hamnet and Hamlet were often used interchangeably back then and this is O‚ÄôFarrell‚Äôs interpretation of what led to Shakespeare‚Äôs masterpiece.

In the first half, Hamnet is about the tender beginnings of a relationship and the complexity of marriage. It‚Äôs about a free spirit and a neurotic writer navigating their different desires and a long-distance relationship. There are sly nods to Shakespeare‚Äôs most famous work, like the fact that William and Agnes are star-crossed lovers as he presumably scribbles down Romeo & Juliet by candlelight or that William‚Äôs relationship with his dad proves Shakespeare‚Äôs daddy issues were in full effect. The subtlety stops there. The second half of Hamnet is unflinching, a devastating portrait of the grief that accompanies unconditional love. At certain moments, Hamnet made me angry; I was begging for a break from the onslaught of emotional tyranny it was reigning over its audience. At others, I was grateful for its vulnerability and unabashed sentimentality. If Zhao and co. were manipulating me into crying so hard I had a headache for hours after the credits rolled, it worked.¬†Anything that succeeds in eliciting that much emotion and draws out these extraordinary performances from two of the best actors of their generation is, to me, a triumph.

When I speak to Mescal and Buckley over Zoom, they‚Äôre a lot gigglier than you may expect considering both are known for playing roles that rip your heart out and give your tear ducts a workout. They are thoughtful, polite, and playfully rib each other with the ease of old friends. Below, the Irish actors talk about the emotional weight of Hamnet, the first movies that made them cry, and gush about their co-star to the hilarious discomfort of the other.

Refinery29: I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve gotten this a lot today but this movie fucked me up. I was sobbing hysterically by the end.¬†

Jessie Buckley and Paul Mescal: [Both laugh].

I feel like people need a disclaimer that they are going to cry a lot. Can you just give a warning or any advice on how to prepare for the emotional experience of watching this film?¬†

Jessie Buckley: To feel is quite scary. To feel at all is scary. I think we try to control what that is in our lives and in some ways, there‚Äôs so much catharsis to connect again to the epicness of just being alive. And this film is so full of love. It‚Äôs so full of the courage to love fully and to live fully, and to lose. And anytime you choose to love, you also choose to potentially lose. You‚Äôre risking to lose somebody in your life. But I think there‚Äôs a lot of catharsis and hope and healing in this film, and you‚Äôre not on your own. There‚Äôs going to be somebody beside you who‚Äôs going to have a tissue, and they‚Äôre going to give it to you, and you‚Äôre going to have a big chat and a hug afterwards and you‚Äôre going to think that was great.

Paul Mescal: [laughs] Okay, that was great!¬†

Make it a community experience!¬†

JB: [laughs] That wasn‚Äôt my experience. I locked myself in a toilet for half an hour afterwards.¬†

Yes, I needed to decompress! Do either of you remember the first movie that made you cry or made you feel like this film does?¬†

JB: Yes, Darby O‚ÄôGill and the Little People [1959]. Because there was a banshee and I thought that was the most terrifying thing in the whole wide world. I was inconsolable. Have you seen it? I mean, it‚Äôs not a huge hitter, it‚Äôs quite niche.

PM: What‚Äôs it called again?¬†

JB: ¬†Darby O‚ÄôGill and the Little People.¬†

PM: That‚Äôs not a real movie.

JB: [laughs] It is a movie!¬†

Paul, what‚Äôs the first movie that made you cry?¬†

JB: He‚Äôs going to say something profound.¬†

PM: No, T√≠r na n√ìg [Into The West, 1992].¬†

JB: Oh yeah, that‚Äôs lovely.¬†

JB and PM [in unison]: The potato and the horse!¬†

JB: Yeah, that made me cry.

Well, you both made me cry. But the movie doesn‚Äôt work without your chemistry. William and Agnes are two big characters to embody and you both did so beautifully. I want to give you a moment to look at each other and gush about working with each other and what makes each other so great.¬†

PM: Jessie is just [laughs] ‚Äî This is not just a performance of the year, this is a performance, and I‚Äôve said this before, but this is going to be studied in drama schools. Actors around the world, if you want to see what great acting is, not only just watch Hamnet, watch anything that Jessie has ever been in, and you‚Äôd be well fed. And that‚Äôs all the time we have for today! [laughs]¬†

JB: No [laughs]. I feel like I‚Äôve met somebody so significant and giant in my life in working with Paul on this. Firstly, he is absolutely‚Ä¶ No, firstly, he has the most‚Ä¶¬†¬†

PM: [laughs] Firstly, Darby O‚ÄôGill and the Little People.¬†

JB: [laughs] No, no! He has such a gigantic human heart, and he‚Äôs such a team player. He holds the biggest parts of you. He can drink a case of you, and not many people can, especially co-leads. Not many people can just, with absolute care and courage, help you to tell the story. I mean this with so much sincerity and belief: he is a movie star, and he wears it ‚Äî¬†

PM: [nervous, uncomfortable laughter]¬†

JB: No, you are! You just are. It‚Äôs true for you, and that‚Äôs because you have this capacity of being a giant. You are a giant person.

PM: I am of average height [laughs].¬†

JB: ¬†[laughs] No, your heart is gigantic. It‚Äôs no coincidence that he‚Äôs going from playing William Shakespeare to Paul McCartney, and being a gladiator. Not many people can manage that, and he can, and that‚Äôs because of who he is as a man.

PM: That was lovely.

title: Bowen Yang & Matt Rogers Curated The Ultimate Cool Girl Gift Guide
text:
Bowen Yang & Matt Rogers Curated The Ultimate Cool Girl Gift Guide

If there‚Äôs one thing we can count on Bowen Yang and Matt Rogers for, it‚Äôs a hyper-specific pop culture reference. For the last decade, the comedic duo have mined the deepest corners of queer cultural zeitgeist on their podcast Las Culturistas, which snagged iHeartRadio‚Äôs Podcast Of The Year Award in 2023. This holiday season, their new Marshalls campaign ‚Äî It‚Äôs Giving Gifts! ‚Äî channels their encyclopedic archive of niche archetypes into the highest form of holiday-season community service: helping shoppers find the perfect present for every type of person in their lives.

From best gifts ‚Äúfor the homebody who loves their sourdough starter more than you, and you have accepted that‚Äù to selections for ‚Äúthe cool girl who is always late and makes you think punctuality is kind of embarrassing‚Äù and ‚Äúthe teen who has so much drip you were left with no choice but to use the word ‚Äú‚Äòdrip‚Äô to describe them‚Äù ‚Äî¬†each gift guide offers meticulously curated, cross-category selections from designer labels and beloved brands at a wide variety of price points.¬†

‚ÄúSaying that you love Marshalls is like ordering Diet Coke for the table,‚Äù Yang tells Refinery29 while we chat in-store at Marshalls in Manhattan. ‚ÄúYou empower other people to say something they thought was buried: ‚ÄòOh, wait, I‚Äôve always loved Marshalls too.‚Äô‚Äù

Below, Yang and Rogers share their best tips for picking the perfect gift, their most formative holiday memories, and the greatest presents they‚Äôve ever given ‚Äî and received.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Let‚Äôs talk about my personal favorite gift-guide archetype ‚Äî gifts for ‚Äúthe cool girl who is always late and makes punctuality seem kind of embarrassing.‚Äù To reference the recurring segment on your podcast ‚Äî what are the cultural moments that made this cool girl who she is today?

Bowen Yang: We all know this girl. We might even be this girl. This girl saw Mean Girls in theaters at least 5 times in 2004. She really imprinted on ‚Äî not Romy and Michelle ‚Äî but she identified with their bullies. Maybe [they identify] with Janeane Garofalo ‚Äôcause they like a quick-smoke cigarette because they have places to be and they are always late to those places.

Matt Rogers: I would say it‚Äôs that girl from high school who you‚Äôre like: ‚ÄúYou learned the wrong thing from Regina George.‚Äù¬† But‚Ä¶ she looked good.

There‚Äôs so many cute purses and shoes in the ‚Äúcool girl‚Äù gift guide. Where is the cool girl wearing these accessories while out and about in Manhattan?

Yang: She‚Äôs taking this to Balthazar, Carbone, the Whitney, the Circle Line Cruise so she can swing around [her purse] while the DJ plays a song on a boat.¬†

Rogers: She‚Äôs going to take this to Zero Bond. She‚Äôs going to walk past Taylor Swift, and Taylor‚Äôs gonna go: ‚ÄúSo sorry, where did you get that bag?‚Äù She‚Äôll say: ‚ÄúMarshalls.‚Äù And she‚Äôs going to wink at Taylor, and Taylor‚Äôs gonna be like: ‚ÄúTravis, we gotta go. Let‚Äôs get to Marshalls.‚Äù¬†
